analytic.title: Reputational Rationality Theory

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Abstract
div.p: Traditionally, research on human judgment and decision making draws on cognitive psychology to identify deviations from normative standards of how decisions ought to be made. These deviations are commonly considered irrational errors and biases. However, even though most decisions are embedded within complex social networks of observers, this approach typically ignores how decisions are perceived by valued audiences. To address this limitation, this article proposes reputational rationality theory: a model of how observers evaluate targets who do (vs. do not) strictly adhere to normative standards of judgment and choice. The theory generates testable predictions for when and why observers positively evaluate error-prone decision makers, termed the benefit of bias hypothesis. To do so, the theory integrates decision, target, and observer characteristics as key conditions under which errors and biases boost reputation (i.e., the set of beliefs or opinions held by observers about a decision maker). In addition, it also specifies contextual factors shaping when and why reputational outcomes are most likely to reinforce decision biases through feedback loops, contributing to their persistence. Given that individuals hold deep impression management goals, reputational rationality theory challenges the unqualified classification of response tendencies that deviate from normative standards as invariably irrational. That is, apparent errors and biases can, under certain theoretical conditions, be reputationally rational. By increasing understanding of the reputational causes and consequences of decision biases, reputational rationality theory can help address long-standing puzzles in judgment and decision making as well as generate fruitful avenues for future research.

The past half century witnessed a scientific revolution investigating to what extent human judgment and decision making lives up to objective standards of rationality (Arkes, 1991; Bazerman Bermudez, 2022;Connolly, Arkes, & Hammond, 2000;Einhorn & Hogarth, 1981;Fischhoff & Broomell, 2020;Gilovich & Griffin, 2010;Gilovich, Griffin, & Kahneman, 2002;Kahneman, Knetsch, & Thaler, 1991;Loewenstein, Rick, & Cohen., 2008;Mellers, Schwartz, & Cooke, 1998;Oaksford & Chater, 2007;Page, 2022;Payne, Bettman, & Johnson, 1992;Risen, 2016;Shafir & LeBoeuf, 2002;Thaler, 1980;Tversky & Kahneman, 1974;Weber & Johnson, 2009;Yates, 1990). Harnessing insights primarily from cognitive psychology (Goldstein, 2023;Kahneman, 1991), behavioral decision researchers identified systematic deviations between descriptive models (i.e., how decisions are actually made) and normative models (i.e., how decisions should be made). As Kahneman (2003) aptly summarized in his Nobel Prize Address, this research program "attempted to obtain a map of bounded rationality, by exploring the systematic biases that separate the beliefs that people have and the choices they make from the optimal beliefs and choices assumed in rational-agent models." Today, an influential view is that cognitive limitations on information processing produce pervasive, pernicious, and perdurable errors and biases in human judgment and decision making (for important critiques, see Cohen, 1981;Dorst, 2023;Gigerenzer, 1996;Gigerenzer & Goldstein, 1996;Lopes, 1991;Oaksford & Chater, 1994;Stanovich & West, 2000).

Despite its influence, this cognitive approach has serious limitations. Critically, even though most decisions are embedded within complex social networks of observers, this approach traditionally ignores how decisions are evaluated by observers. From an experienced politician before an imminent election to an exhausted employee before a long-awaited annual review, individuals care deeply about how they are perceived by others. Traditional cognitive models are limited to the extent that they do not measure reputational outcomes: the set of beliefs or opinions held by observers about a decision maker (c.f., Jordan, 2023).

To address this limitation, this manuscript proposes Reputational Rationality Theory (RRT). RRT generates testable predictions regarding when and why observers confer reputational rewards on targets who exhibit apparent errors and biases, termed the benefit of bias hypothesis. A key tenet of RRT is that maintaining a positive reputation holds value. A positive reputation generates trust and cooperation; a negative reputation does the opposite, impeding personal and professional functioning. It is therefore critical to understand how observers evaluate decision makers. While RRT is primarily concerned with how observers evaluate targets' decisions (i.e., how reputations are influenced by decisions), it has secondary implications for how targets shift their decisions based on the presence of observers (i.e., how decisions are influenced by perceived reputational incentives).

RRT makes multiple theoretical and practical contributions. RRT provides a unifying framework for previously disparate findings demonstrating that observers reward decision makers who fall victim to supposed errors and biases. Existing research provides converging evidence that deviating from normative standards can boost a decision maker's reputation. This evidence includes loss-gain framing effects on risk preferences (Dorison & Heller, 2022), overconfidence (Tenney, Meikle, Hunsaker, Anderson, & Moore, 2019), escalation of commitment (Staw & Ross, 1980), lack of Bayesian updating (Cao, Kleiman-Weiner, & Banaji, 2019), and uncalculating cooperation (Jordan, Hoffman, Nowak, & Rand, 2016). Tying together unconnected research findings in an integrative framework can deepen psychological understanding of when, why, how, and for whom they occur.

RRT extends existing research using social functionalist approaches to investigate judgment and decision making (Tetlock, 2002). 1 While most of the experimental study of human rationality (and its shortcomings) has drawn on cognitive psychology, several major social psychological theories have emphasized the role of observer reactions in the maintenance or reduction of biased behavior. For example, research on accountability by Tetlock and colleagues generated and tested theoretically grounded predictions for when and why the potential for evaluation by observers amplifies (e.g., Tetlock & Boettger, 1994), attenuates (e.g., Kruglanski, & Freund, 1983;Simonson & Staw, 1992), or has no effect on cognitive biases (for review, see Lerner & Tetlock, 1999 As a complement, RRT provides testable predictions for how observers form evaluations.

These include which biases they will reward, which aspects of reputation will be influenced, what types of targets are more likely to be rewarded, and what types of audiences will be more likely to reward such behavior. This article also discusses when reputational pressures are more (vs. less) likely to translate to material outcomes relevant to a target's goals. In doing so, RRT provides a rich foundation for future work examining the conditions under which observer reactions maintain biased behavior dynamically over time-beyond decision makers' initial expectations in the moment, as is typically studied in prior work. 1 Scholars across scientific disciplines have long recognized the central position of a need for social connection (Durkheim, 1925(Durkheim, /1976Goffman, 1959;Mead, 1934;Vygotsky, 1934Vygotsky, /1978. Novel decision making models that directly incorporate a central role for reputation remain influential within psychology (e.g., Chaudhry & Loewenstein, 2019;Fitzsimons, Finkel, & vanDellen, 2015;Gallus, Reiff, Kamenica, & Fiske, 2022;Jordan & Rand, 2020), as well as in related fields including economics (Kreps & Wilson, 1982), organizational behavior (Bolino, Long, & Turnley, 2016), marketing (Berman, Levine, Barasch, & Small, 2015;Berman & Silver, 2022), and political science (Kertzer & Brutger, 2016;Renshon, Yarhi-Milo, & Kertzer, 2023). 2 Related research on impression management has also examined how observers behave in response to a target's behavior, particularly where the target is assumed to be engaging in self-promoting or manipulative behavior (Bolino, Long, & Turnley, 2016;Chaudhry & Loewenstein, 2019;Sezer, 2022).

RRT also bears on long-standing debates taking a cognitive approach to judgment and decision making. Debates over human rationality have raged for decades (Gigerenzer, 1996;Kahneman & Tversky, 1996; for a recent review, see Bermudez, 2022). For example, in direct opposition to Kahneman and Tversky's influential heuristics-and-biases research program (Kahneman, Slovic, & Tversky, 1982), Gigerenzer and colleagues argued that simple cognitive heuristics are often more accurate (and thus rational) than highly complex statistical methods, despite using less information (e.g., Gigerenzer, 1996Gigerenzer, , 2008Gigerenzer, , 2018Gigerenzer & Gassmaier, 2011;Gigerenzer & Goldstein, 1996;Gigerenzer, Hertwig, & Pachur, 2011;Gigerenzer & Selten, 2001; but see also Kahneman & Klein, 2009). While RRT certainly does not provide a final verdict on this long-standing debate, it can inject new evidence. Indeed, over three decades ago, Tetlock (1992, p. 333) postulated that "many response tendencies that look flawed within a narrowly cognitive or microeconomic perspective can be viewed as prudent responses to the social world within which people live and work."

Building on this postulate, RRT provides a framework for understanding when and why these alleged errors and biases may be considered socially prudent. More concretely, RRT specifies conditions under which apparent errors and biases can be reputationally rational because they yield sufficient social rewards from observers. To be clear, RRT does not suggest that biased behavior should always be considered reputationally rational, but rather that it can under theoretically grounded conditions where social rewards offset costs associated with decision biases (for related discussion, see Lerner & Tetlock, 1999;Tetlock, 1998Tetlock, , 2002.

Finally, RRT not only helps address old puzzles in judgment and decision making, but also unlocks novel avenues of inquiry. Can a decision be considered rational if it inadvertently fulfills a target's reputational goals-even if the target was unaware that it would? And what communication strategies can individuals (and leaders) use to maintain trust when making rational decisions? While current evidence bearing on these questions is relatively scant, this manuscript proposes theoretically grounded hypotheses to answer them. This article proceeds as follows. Section I reviews existing yet formerly disparate evidence for the benefit of bias hypothesis. Section II-the heart of the manuscript-proposes RRT and identifies its key psychological components. In doing so, it specifies decision, target, and audience characteristics as key conditions under which errors and biases boost reputation. It also discusses empirical evidence for these components and sets out testable hypotheses.

Drawing on the idea of feedback loops, Section III identifies additional contextual features modulating the link between reputational outcomes as judged by an observer and material outcomes for a target. This section bears directly on the question of when reputations are more (vs. less) likely to offset costs associated with decision biases. Section IV argues that RRT not only sheds new light on canonical puzzles within judgment and decision making, but also emphasizes underappreciated areas of inquiry. Finally, Section V concludes with a call for future research.

div.head: I. Existing evidence for the benefit of bias hypothesis
div.p: Over four decades after the founding of the field, Gilovich and Griffin (2010, p. 559) observed that "The roots of judgment and decision making in mathematical decision theory, in reasoning, and in statistical prediction guaranteed a pronounced, if not exclusive, focus on cognitive mechanisms of judgment and choice." While prior research using this cognitive approach has documented dozens of decision biases (Pronin & Hazel, 2023; but see Yang, Li, & Hsee, 2023), Section I provides a selective review of research from five domains in which researchers have examined their reputational consequences. In doing so, it integrates formerly disparate evidence supporting the benefit of bias hypothesis: that third-party observers can confer reputational rewards on targets who demonstrate supposedly irrational behavior.

Because both reputation and rationality are multifaceted and interdisciplinary constructs, it is useful to define them precisely. For now, the present manuscript defines reputation narrowly as the set of first-order beliefs an observer holds about a target's qualities in the moment (c.f., Jordan, 2023). While this operationalization most closely matches the evidence reviewed below, it is of course not the only way reputation can be defined. Most notably, reputation can sometimes imply a set of beliefs an observer holds about how others perceive a target's qualities (i.e., a second-order set of beliefs) or can also imply a longer-lasting set of evaluations. I return to these alternatives later in the manuscript.

Consistent with influential research in behavioral decision making (Kahneman, Slovic, & Tversky, 1982), the majority of the manuscript adopts a definition of procedural rationality from neoclassical economics and rational choice theory. Exemplified by Kahneman's Nobel Prize Address quoted in the opening paragraph of this article, rationality is usually defined as adherence to choice axioms, where such adherence is classified as normatively correct (c.f., Nielsen & Rehbeck, 2022). Pillars of this approach include consistency of choices, maximization of expected utility, and adherence to Bayesian updating (Savage, 1954). For better or worse, scholars using this framework often (but not always) use words like suboptimal, biased, and irrational somewhat interchangeably to describe deviations from choice axioms and/or normative models. As such, most of the manuscript accepts past classifications of many behavioral tendencies as errors and biases (e.g., loss-gain framing effects on risk preferences). Traditionally, this behavioral decision-making approach does not consider the social and impression management goals held by a decision maker when classifying judgments and decisions as biased, suboptimal, and/or irrational-a challenge RRT takes up toward the end of the manuscript, especially in the context of ecological and instrumental rationality (c.f., Viale, 2021).

These operationalizations of reputation and rationality necessitate excluding at least two related types of evidence. First, RRT excludes evidence that does not have a clear normative standard. Examples include important related work on how observers positively evaluate individuals who give to ineffective charities (e.g., Berman & Silver, 2022;Caviola, Schubert, & Greene, 2021;Law, Campbell, & Gaesser, 2022) or who make deontological moral judgments (e.g., Bostyn & Roets, 2017;Everett, Pizarro, & Crockett, 2016;Everett, Faber, Savulescu, & Crockett, 2018;Rom, Weiss, & Conway, 2017;Sacco, Brown, Lustgraaf, & Hugenberg, 2017).

Second, because there are no direct measures of reputation, RRT excludes work, mostly in the literature on game theory, revealing that seemingly irrational behavior can provide a competitive advantage in strategic settings. For example, Schelling's (1960) influential model of strategic ignorance-in which blinding oneself to certain information confers an advantage against a counterpart in a zero-sum game-does not fall under the purview of the benefit of bias hypothesis. In these cases, the supposedly irrational behavior allows the decision maker to fulfill their original utility maximization goals, but it does not do so by conferring reputational rewards-a precondition of fulfilling the benefit of bias hypothesis. Kahneman and Tversky (1979 catalyzed the modern research program on human judgment and decision making, in part by developing prospect theory as a descriptive model of decision making under risk. One key consequence of prospect theory is the loss-gain framing effect: the tendency for individuals to prefer risk-averse choices when options are framed as gains and risk-seeking choices when options are framed as losses, even when choice sets are otherwise equivalent. For example, people tend to prefer a risk-averse policy that saves 200 lives for sure when outcomes are framed as lives saved, but prefer a risk-seeking policy with a onethird chance to save 600 lives when outcomes are framed as lives lost. Strikingly, such effects replicate among professional physicians (McNeil et al., 1982) and persist across 19 countries and 13 languages (Ruggeri et al., 2020). Despite their prevalence, loss-gain framing effects on risk preferences are often considered irrational mistakes: Kahneman (2003) observed that "invariance is an essential aspect of rationality, which is violated in demonstration of framing effects." Bazerman and Moore (2009, p. 65) agreed: "rational decision makers should be immune to the framing of choices." (for important critiques, see Bermudez, 2022;Gigerenzer & Gaissmaier, 2011;Gigerenzer & Goldstein, 1996;Sher & McKenzie, 2006).

div.head: A. Decision making under risk
div.p: Considering the reputational consequences of such choices paints a more nuanced picture. Specifically, recent research reveals that observers penalize decision makers who do not

show loss-gain framing effects on risk preferences (Dorison & Heller, 2022; see also Dorison, 2022). The authors conducted three experiments in the context of loss-gain framing introduced by Tversky (1979, 1981). While third-party observers rewarded decision makers who made risk-seeking (vs. risk-averse) choices when choice outcomes were framed as losses, this result reversed when outcomes were framed as gains. Such a reversal held across multiple participant samples and across three different social perceptions (warmth, competence, confidence). Put another way, the choice that made the target look good reversed depending on the frame in which the choice was made-even though traditional models classify attention to how decisions are framed as a suboptimal mistake. Beyond social impressions, observers also sent more money to people in a dictator game who made frame-consistent choices, revealing that material benefits can flow to individuals who deviate from canonical choice axioms.

Penalties for appropriate risk preferences can also persist within a given frame. In related work, Wu and colleagues (Wu, Heath, & Knez, 2003) provided evidence for a timidity error when managers evaluate their employees' risk preferences. The authors define this error as incorrectly judging another person as too risk averse (i.e., timid)-even in contexts where one's counterpart is well-calibrated (i.e., the probabilities they assigned better matched objectivelyknown probabilities). In two studies of MBA students at the University of Chicago, participants assigned to the role of evaluators rated a target on a variety of social perceptions (e.g., knowledge, confidence). Evaluators derogated timid targets, and in turn were less willing to work with them on a future task-even though the timid targets were often better calibrated.

Altogether, prior research makes clear that consistent and calibrated risk preferences do not necessarily translate to positive evaluations from observers. Instead, and supporting the benefit of bias hypothesis, inconsistent and mis-calibrated risk preferences can-under certain conditions-be rewarded.

div.head: B. Overconfidence
div.p: Overconfidence, sometimes termed "the mother of all biases," is often considered the costliest of the dozens of biases of human judgment (Bazerman & Moore, 2013;Kahneman, 2011;Klayman et al., 1999;Moore, 2023). Studying contexts with objective standards of accuracy, researchers have regularly documented that people have excess certainty in their beliefs and predictions (Moore, 2023). Indeed, it is difficult to reconcile the empirical findings on overconfidence with an unbiased model of human judgment (Bazerman & Moore, 2013;Kahneman, 2011). Given its material costs-such as wasted time, money, and energy-it is perhaps puzzling why it persists in its many forms. One answer is that some forms of overconfidence, such as overprecision (i.e., the excessive certainty in the accuracy of one's judgment), are a property of system thinking.
That is, individuals (and even machines) simply cannot process all the ways in which they may be incorrect (Moore, 2023).
But given its omnipresence, it seems likely that overconfidence is multiply determined.
For example, presidential candidates regularly express overconfidence in their electoral prospects, despite access to high-quality polling data. So, what else drives overconfidence?

Recent research demonstrates that overconfidence can be socially reinforced under predictable conditions. When confidence is not scored against concrete performance, more confident targets tend to be perceived more positively (Price & Stone, 2004;Sah, Moore, & MacCoun, 2013;Tenney et al., 2019). For example, participants in one study were more likely to hire a candidate who expressed great confidence in their abilities in a prior task (e.g., "I would say that I performed better than the vast majority of people who completed the task") than a candidate who was more cautious in their appraisal (e.g., "Compared to other people who completed the task, I
probably scored below average"; Tenney et al., 2019). This result has been replicated in other contexts such as eyewitness testimony, as well (Tenney, Spellman, & MacCoun, 2008).

While such social benefits of confidence tend to be attenuated when scored against actual performance, they usually do not reverse (Anderson, Brion, Moore, & Kennedy, 2012;Kennedy, Anderson, & Moore, 2013). That is, even when targets were exposed as overconfident in studies like the one described above, they were often still perceived just as positively by others as those who were better calibrated (for related work, see Cheng et al., 2021;Schwardmann & Van Der Weele, 2019;Soldà, Ke, von Hippel, & Page, 2021;Van Zant, 2022).

Such effects are important not only theoretically but also practically. Connecting intrapersonal cognition to interpersonal evaluations and societal outcomes, Belmi and colleagues (2020) demonstrated not only that higher-class individuals are more likely to be overconfident, but also that doing so helps them attain greater social rank. For example, in one laboratory study modeled after a mock job interview, higher-class participants were more overconfident than their lower-class counterparts. This overconfidence triggered perceptions of competence, which in turn predicted likelihood of attaining social rank (in this case, being perceived as more hirable).

Seen through this lens, reputational benefits for overconfidence can reinforce and propagate existing societal inequalities. Future research would benefit from modeling this approach that cuts across levels of analysis with other decision contexts.

Altogether, research on overconfidence reveals that it can yield social rewards, despite diverging from benchmarks of accuracy. These rewards are especially pronounced when confidence is not scored against performance, and can contribute to reinforcing existing societal inequalities when left unchecked.

div.head: C. Escalation of commitment
div.p: Sometimes the direct result of overconfidence (Ronay et al., 2017), escalation of commitment refers to the robust tendency for decision makers to persist with failing courses of action (Brockner, 1992;Sleesman et al., 2012Sleesman et al., , 2018Staw, 1981). Often a direct result of the sunk cost fallacy (Arkes & Blumer, 1985;Olivola, 2018;Thaler, 1980), escalation plagues personal, professional, and political decisions, ranging from exhausted presidents continuing unwinnable wars to sweaty visitors at Disneyland overheating in lengthy lines.

While prior research has identified numerous cognitive factors driving costly escalation (for meta-analytic review, see Sleesman et al., 2012), recent research empirically investigated whether escalation of commitment can foster trust (Dorison, Umphres, & Lerner, 2022; see also Kanodia et al., 1989;Staw, 1981;Tetlock, 2000). To test this hypothesis, Dorison and colleagues (2022) had participants read a widely used hypothetical vignette in which a leader must choose whether to continue investing in a radar-blank plane after a competitor has released a superior product (Arkes & Blumer, 1985;Feldman & Wong, 2018;Olivola, 2018). Even though the new radar-blank plane developed by the company appeared doomed for failure, decision makers who escalated commitment in this hypothetical scenario were perceived as more trustworthy on multiple dimensions of trust (e.g., both integrity-based trust and benevolence-based trust).
Further, in a financially incentivized trust game, observers entrusted 29% more money to escalators compared to de-escalators.

This finding is in line with a classic finding documented by Staw and Ross (1980; see also Staw, 1981). Staw and Ross (1980) investigated how individuals (including practicing managers and undergraduates) evaluated a leader's (here, an administrator's) course of action.
The authors found what they termed a hero effect in the form of an interaction between consistency of the administrator's action and its eventual success. In the authors' words (p. 252),
"administrators who stick to a dubious course of action, which eventually does succeed, are rated even higher than one would predict from two main effects of consistency and success acting alone."

Consistent with decades of theorizing, multiple lines of research thus provide evidence that escalating commitment to failing courses of action-often the direct result of biased attention to sunk costs-can promote trust. This critical social reward is often conferred despite escalation's material costs.

div.head: D. Beliefs and belief updating
div.p: Once individuals expose themselves to the relevant information to form a judgment or make a decision, what should they do next? Normative models dictate a clear answer: integrate prior knowledge with the new information to form new beliefs (i.e., follow Bayes Rule). However, doing so can have reputational risks when this process conflicts with societal values. For example, consider one man and one woman, both of whom put out a fire. Which is more likely to be a firefighter? Given the higher base rates for men (vs. women) to be firefighters, Bayesian rationality imposes that the man is more likely to be a firefighter. Despite this fact, observers morally derogate and financially punish targets who follow this Bayesian prescription and say that the man is more likely to be a firefighter, likely because it conflicts with norms concerning fairness (Cao, Kleiman-Weiner, & Banaji, 2019).
Cao and colleagues 2019 (Kreps, Laurin, & Merritt, 2017) revealed that leaders who changed their minds on moral issues (e.g., same-sex marriage or the death penalty)

were perceived as ineffective, hypocritical, and less worthy of support-even by observers who agreed with the new position. In a separate stream of five studies, John and colleagues (2019) revealed that observers evaluated targets (including entrepreneurs in a pitch competition) who did not change their mind in the face of incontrovertible evidence as more confident, but less intelligent. Relatedly, the authors found that decision makers often refuse to back down to "save face" and avoid embarrassment. Taken together, these two projects provide evidence that changing one's mind (as often is dictated by Bayes Theory) is reputationally risky, especially in cases when doing so violates broader norms (e.g., hypocrisy).

Finally, Blunden and colleagues (2019) examined belief updating in the context of advice seeking, shedding light on important nuance for the effects described above. While prior work seems to suggest that observers do not want targets to incorporate advice (and thus change their minds), might this change when the advice comes from the observer herself? In a series of clever studies, Blunden and colleagues (2019) investigated potential interpersonal costs associated with seeking advice from multiple advisors, a strategy regularly proposed to increase accuracy of judgments. Across nine programmatic studies, advisors disapproved of advisees who ignored their advice. These effects persisted across topics (e.g., musical instruments, geography, sports, or current events), but tended to be stronger when the advisor felt greater expertise. As a result, the authors concluded that advice seekers must consider interpersonal goals alongside decision accuracy ones-because they regularly conflict. 3

Altogether, prior research paints a relatively nuanced picture regarding the reputational consequences of beliefs and belief updating. While observers derogate targets who follow Bayesian rationality in forming and updating their beliefs, they also derogate targets who do not update their beliefs in response to the observers' own advice. In both cases, social evaluations can diverge in systematic ways from standards of accuracy.

div.head: E. Uncalculating cooperation
div.p: Traditionally, economic rationality emphasizes self-interest as a primary motivator of human behavior (Becker, 1976). When altruism and cooperation do occur, it is often explained through the mechanism of reciprocity; these theorists argue that the short-term costs of selflessness are offset by long-term benefits (e.g., Trivers, 1971). And yet, some forms of cooperation-such as extreme cooperation or cooperation with anonymous strangers-resist this traditional explanation, therefore persisting as an apparent violation of the standard of self-interest dictated by neoclassical economic models.
Jordan and colleagues (2016) provided evidence for the benefit of bias hypothesis in one of these puzzling cooperation contexts. The authors investigated uncalculating cooperation:

cooperative behavior that is not conditional on the precise cost of cooperating in a specific situation or context. For example, a friend might agree to help a former roommate move apartments, without first asking how long the endeavor will take. Taking a reputational approach and using a variety of financially incentivized economic games, Jordan and colleagues revealed that uncalculating cooperation is used to signal trustworthiness. That is, individuals who agree to cooperate without first taking the time to calculate costs and benefits-typically considered a suboptimal strategy-are trusted more by observers, even when the observers are not themselves the beneficiary of the cooperative act (see also Jensen, Levine, White, & Huppert, 2021).
Strikingly, decision makers appear aware of this benefit: they are more likely to engage in uncalculating cooperation when their decision process is observed (vs. private).

div.head: F. Summary
div.p: The primary aim of this section was to review unconnected research supporting the benefit of bias hypothesis. While there is now converging evidence that strict adherence to normative choice models can yield social costs for a decision maker, this budding research literature has some important conceptual limitations. Empirical work has typically considered one type of decision at a time, often without considering how such dynamics may generalize to other judgments and choices. It has also typically considered one aspect of reputation, often without considering how such results may generalize to other inferences about a target's character.

div.head: II. Reputational Rationality Theory
div.p: RRT aims to provide an integrative framework that grounds theoretical predictions to answer the questions raised above. In doing so, it not only provides increased understanding of past research supporting the benefit of bias hypothesis, but also yields increased predictive power for future research examining when and why the hypothesis is most (vs. least) likely to hold. Note: RRT proposes that observers evaluate a target in part based on whether they agree with the choice made by the target; in turn, these evaluations can trigger behavior toward the target. In certain cases, this process can produce dynamics in which biased behavior by targets is rewarded by observers, in turn reinforcing biased behavior. Characteristics of the decision (e.g., which bias is being shown), the target (e.g., whether the target is high vs. low status), and the observer (e.g., decision making competence) can shape the likelihood the observer agrees with the target's choice and/or whether such agreement confers reputational advantages. Finally, contextual features (e.g., the relationship between the observer and target) shape whether reputational outcomes translate to behavioral ones relevant to the target's goals, in turn reinforcing biased behavior through feedback loops.

Two limitations of RRT as currently constructed merit note. First, while RRT provides a rich set of components and mechanisms, it is not meant to be exhaustive. While leaving open the possibility for future additions, the current construction of the theory attempts to strike a balance between parsimony and predictive power. Second, RRT treats decision, target, and audience characteristics as independent factors. Identifying the conditions under which these characteristics interact with each other will be undoubtedly complex-and should be a fruitful line of empirical research going forward.

As a starting point, Section II begins by introducing observer agreement with the choice made by the decision maker as a central factor determining when biased behavior can trigger reputational rewards. Then-by introducing characteristics of decisions, targets, and observersit expands on the evidence for how, when, and why such effects are likely to hold, be eliminated, or even reverse.

div.head: A. Observer agreement with target's choice
div.p: RRT begins with the reflection that observers themselves-much like the targets they evaluateroutinely fall victim to cognitive biases. For example, in the context of loss-gain framing effects on risk preferences, using the classic "influenza problem," Tversky and Kahneman (1981, problem 1) revealed that while 72% of individuals made the risk-averse choice when outcomes were framed as gains, 78% of individuals made the risk-seeking choice when outcomes were framed as losses. While such dramatic preference reversals are quite rare, this finding illustrates the broader point that deviations from rational choice models are pervasive. These deviations stubbornly persist both with experts and with financial incentives (e.g., Camerer & Hogarth, 1999;Dawes, Faust, & Meehl, 1989;Enke et al., 2021;Northcraft & Neale, 1987;Massey & Thaler, 2013;McNeil, Pauker, Sox, & Tversky, 1982;Schwitzgebel & Cushman, 2015;Shanteau, 1992;Simmons & Massey, 2012).

Multiple research streams across academic traditions provide converging theorizing that individuals reputationally reward others who make similar choices to themselves. As far back as 370 BCE, Plato observed that "similarity begets friendship" (Plato, 1968, p. 837;Prinstein & Dodge, 2008). More recently, a large and interdisciplinary empirical literature provides evidence for homophily: the tendency to prefer to affiliate with others who share important beliefs, preferences, or characteristics, most notably political ideology (Dehghani et al., 2016;DiPrete et al., 2011;Halberstam & Knight, 2016;Huber & Malhotra, 2017;Kossinets & Watts, 2009;McPherson et al., 2001). For example, in economic games, individuals share more money with co-partisans (Foddy et al., 2009;Rand et al., 2009); they also view them as both warmer and more competent (Fiske, 2015;Finkel et al., 2020).

But strong political beliefs are not necessary for homophily (McPherson, Smith-Lovin, & Cook, 2001). In an early demonstration, Byrne (1961) revealed that strangers with similar (rather than dissimilar) attitudes on 26 different issues (e.g., Western movies or classical music) indicated more positive feelings toward each other. Tajfel (1970) provided a controlled experimental replication, demonstrating that minimal group differences as trivial as disagreement about the quantity of dots on a page were sufficient to produce changes in the amount of money individuals shared with each other. People who were led to believe that they were an "overestimator" of the number of dots on the page shared more money with another over-estimator;
under-estimators favored other under-estimators. Unbeknownst to the research participants, the labels were fictitious for both groups.

This theorizing and evidence are consistent with that from a separate research stream on naïve realism: the tendency for individuals to consider their views and beliefs to be accurate and unfiltered representations of reality (sometimes called the "objectivity illusion;" Pronin et al., 2004;Robinson et al., 1995;Ross, 2018). While traditionally studied in the context of partisan conflict and negotiation, research on naïve realism theorizes that individuals regularly consider their beliefs and opinions to be true and objective. As such, when disagreement occurs-be it voting for a political candidate or estimating the number of dots on a page-observers often make negative attributions about the target's lack of information or biased judgment (Pronin, Gilovich, & Ross, 2004). Research supporting the naïve realism hypothesis spans decades and fields, ranging from conflict between Israelis and Palestinians (Robinson, Keltner, Ward, & Ross, 1995) to conflict between ballroom dancing partners (Minson, Liberman, & Ross, 2011). Recent work provides evidence that negative attributions about disagreement persist even in contexts that individuals themselves acknowledge are subjective, such as art (Cheek, Blackman, & Pronin, 2021). In fact, research on halo effects (Nisbett & Wilson, 1977;Wetzel, Wilson, & Kort, 1981) suggests that such inferences can be quite broad in nature (but see Wallace, Craig, & Wegener, 2024;Wallace, Wegener, & Petty, 2020 While the observer agreement pathway provides an intuitively compelling explanation for the benefit of bias hypothesis, it would be astonishing if every cognitive bias was socially rewarded and reputationally reinforced in every culture (for related work, see Dong, van Prooijen, & van Lange, 2021). It is also unlikely that broad inferences will hold across contexts.

These boundary conditions, exceptions, and reversals are essential to deepening our understanding of the relationship between decision biases and reputation. RRT proposes three sets of key components that shape such reputational outcomes: decision characteristics, target characteristics, and audience characteristics.

div.head: B. Decision Characteristics
div.p: Decision contexts vary dramatically across multiple dimensions. Among other features, they can vary not only in the type of decision being observed (e.g., escalation of commitment vs. risktaking vs. procrastination), but also in the type of disagreement being evaluated (e.g., the observer is more vs. less extreme than the target). Each aspect of the decision can influence (a) the probability that an observer disagrees with the target's choice, (b) the inferences that an observer draws about a target once disagreement occurs, or (c) some combination of both. Of note, different decision characteristics may preferentially influence different mechanisms. As illustrative examples, two such decision features are detailed below.
i.

div.head: Type of bias
div.p: Research on bias blind spot (i.e., the general tendency for humans to detect bias more often in others than themselves; Pronin & Hazel, 2023;Pronin, Lin, & Ross, 2002;Scopelliti et al., 2015) can shed light on which biases are likely to be rewarded (vs. penalized) by observers and which aspects of reputation are most likely to be affected. Bias blind spot is often the result of the objectivity illusion (described above, often termed naïve realism; : the conviction that one sees the world "as it really is." As a direct result, differences with others are typically attributed to a counterpart's bias rather than one's own-because one's own views are perceived as objective.

The bias blind spot is widespread, but it is not immutable. In some select cases in which the experience of bias is cognitively available, the phenomenon can reverse. That is, individuals attribute higher levels of bias to themselves than others when the experience of bias is available to introspection. For example, Pronin and colleagues (2002) hypothesized and found that individuals attribute higher levels of procrastination to themselves than others. This empirical result is consistent with a large literature on want/should conflicts (Milkman, Rogers, & Bazerman, 2008, which highlight the fact that individuals regularly accept that they exercise too little or that they eat too much dessert. Indeed, prior research on present-focused preferences (i.e., the tendency for individuals to be more likely to choose an action that generates short-term utility if the short-term utility is immediate rather than following a delay; Cohen, ii.

div.head: Direction of bias
div.p: Homophily refers to the general tendency to like others who share important traits with oneself.

As a complement to homophily, acrophily refers to the tendency prefer to affiliate with others with more extreme (vs. moderate) views (Goldenberg et al., 2023). Whereas bias blind spot presented a moderator based on which bias is being demonstrated when disagreement occurs, acrophily presents a moderator based on which direction the disagreement occurs. That is, how costly a disagreement is depends not just on the magnitude of the disagreement, but also on the direction of the disagreement.
Imagine a moderate liberal named Dan, who has the option of inviting one of two colleagues to lunch: Leonard (who is a weak liberal) or Jeremy (who is a strong liberal).

Acrophily would predict that Dan would select Jeremy, all else equal. And in four studies, Goldenberg and colleagues (2023) provided evidence for exactly this process: partisans preferred to maintain social ties not only with individuals whose views were similar to their own (reflecting homophily), but also with individuals whose views were more extreme than their own (reflecting acrophily).

Just as strong political beliefs are not necessary for homophily to occur, the same may be true for acrophily. Consider again Dan, but this time imagine he is moderately susceptible to sunk-cost bias. He finds himself escalating commitment moderately often, all things considered, and believes doing so is the correct course of action (that is, he is a naïve realist). Dan now has the opportunity of inviting one of two colleagues to launch a new business venture: Leonard (who is weakly susceptible to sunk-cost bias) or Jeremy (who is strongly susceptible to sunk-cost bias). Holding the quantity of disagreements equal, acrophily would again predict that Dan would select Jeremy.

div.head: C. Target Characteristics
div.p: Just as decision contexts vary, so do the people making decisions. RRT integrates how different characteristics of the target influence the process through which observers evaluate them. As with decision characteristics, target characteristics may influence (a) the probability that an observer disagrees with the target's choice, (b) the inferences that an observer draws about a target once disagreement occurs, or (c) some combination of both.

div.head: i. Status
div.p: Status differences are omnipresent. Some colleagues are perceived as experts whose advice can be trusted; others, the opposite. Some organizations are considered paragons of integrity; others, not so much. While precise definitions vary, influential prior work defines social status as the extent to which an individual or group is respected or admired by others (Magee & Galinsky, 2008). 4

Status plays two distinct roles in RRT. First, status may increase the observer's likelihood of agreeing with the observed choice. Prior research demonstrates that individuals higher in status (or power) are more persuasive (Briñol, Petty, Durso, & Rucker, 2017;Magee & Galinsky, 2008; see also Horcajo, Petty, & Briñol, 2010). To the extent that high-status people are more persuasive, it will reduce disagreement with observers-perhaps regardless of whether the target makes a biased (vs. unbiased) choice. In this way, high-status targets' choices serve as stronger anchors than their low-status counterparts' choices do.

Second, holding constant any persuasive benefits, status may buffer against the reputational costs of disagreement. Scholars have long theorized that high-status individuals are perceived as more competent (Magee & Galinsky, 2008). For example, in one classic experiment, Sande and colleagues documented the mere position effect: observers perceived those who were randomly assigned to the high-status position of supervisor more positively than those randomly assigned to the low-status position of worker, even when this randomization was made salient (Sande, Ellard, & Ross, 1986; see also Humphrey, 1985). But beyond having a higher baseline of perceived competence, high-status individuals may also be relatively insulated from the negative repercussions of violating social norms (Hollander, 1958). For example, individuals who are relatively higher in status face lower penalties for disconfirming expectancies (for review, see Magee & Galinsky, 2008). In the context of RRT, disconfirming expectancies can come in the form of disagreeing with the choice of the observer.
This second effect may be more relevant to competence (vs. warmth) related evaluations.

Prior work links status directly to perceived expertise and competence (Magee & Galinsky, 2008). The empirical evidence for this link is substantial: status and competence judgments correlate at above .75 across 19 countries (Cuddy, Fiske, & Glick, 2007). Importantly, individuals appear to act on this belief: Swencionis and Fiske (2016) Harvard; NASA). Others are considered low status. Prior research also makes clear that individuals often rely on demographic information-such as race, gender, or ethnicity-as heuristic cues for social status (Fiske, Cuddy, Glick, & Xu, 2018). Future research is needed to consider how these different status cues intersect when observers evaluate a targ`et's decision.

Altogether, status-as one example of a target characteristic-can play an important role in shaping the likelihood that the benefit of bias hypothesis holds. More concretely, status may increase the probability that an observer agrees with the target's choice and/or that disagreement will not be penalized. Further, such effects may be especially strong for competence, rather than warmth.

div.head: D. Observer Characteristics
div.p: RRT has focused so far on how agreement between an observer and target can trigger positive evaluations, even for biased decisions. It has also specified how characteristics of the decision environment and target can interact with this process. Such effects may also depend on characteristics of the audience. Different audiences may be more vs. less likely to agree with biased choices; they also may be more vs. less likely to disparage targets who make different choices than they themselves prefer-or a combination of both. This section reviews a few such observer characteristics that prior research suggests are likely to play an especially central role in such processes.

div.head: i. Decision-making competence
div.p: Scholars have proposed a wide range of measures capturing general decision-making ability.

Perhaps most relevant to the present investigation is a measure of decision-making competence developed by Bruine de Bruin and colleagues (Bruine de Bruin, Parker, & Fischhoff, 2007; for related work, see Stanovich & West, 1998, 2000. This individual difference measure includes a set of seven behavioral tasks, each tapping a distinct yet related skill (e.g., resistance to framing; resistance to sunk costs; applying decision rules). Individuals who are less likely to fall victim to decision-making biases are classified as higher in decision-making competence. In turn, it is almost definitionally true that audiences higher in decision-making competence are less likely to agree with the biased behavior of a target-and therefore would show a reduced likelihood of demonstrating the benefit of bias.

It is not clear that individual differences in decision-making competence would play a role in modulating the effect of disagreement on evaluations, although it is possible that it would do so. That is, while individuals who are higher in decision-making competence are almost certainly more likely to identify irrational behavior as such, they may be no more likely to penalize it conditional on identifying it.

Other related measures of decision-making ability also merit note and could play a similar logical role in this evaluation process. For example, general measures of intelligence (e.g., performance on the Standardized Achievement Test) or tendency toward cognitive reflection (Frederick, 2005) could also play key moderating roles to the extent that they are negatively correlated with an audience member's susceptibility to a relevant decision bias.

div.head: ii. Bias blind spot
div.p: As described above, bias blind spot refers to the general tendency to perceive greater levels of bias in others than in oneself. Certain people are higher in bias blind spot than others: while Barry might perceive others as much more biased than he is himself, Evan might be more evenhanded in his evaluations. Perhaps surprisingly, bias blind spot has little-to-no relationship with actual decision-making ability (Scopelliti et al., 2015). Instead, bias blind spot primarily reflects an index of self-other comparisons. In line with this interpersonal conceptualization, prior research reveals that individuals higher in bias blind spot are less likely to take advice from others (Scopelliti et al., 2015).

While RRT theorizes that individual differences in decision-making competence and bias blind spot both play an important role in shaping observer reactions to deviations from normative standards of choice, it posits different psychological mechanisms for how they do so. As described above, RRT predicts that individual differences in decision-making competence shift the probability of observers disagreeing with the biased choice of a target, while holding constant the size of the penalty that disagreement carries conditional on occurring. In contrast, RRT predicts that individual differences in bias blind spot increases the penalty that disagreement carries-without shifting the probability of observers disagreeing with the biased choice of a target. Put another way, penalties for disagreement may be stronger among those higher in bias blind spot, even if the probability of disagreeing with a biased behavior remains unchanged.
iii.

div.head: Receptiveness to opposing views
div.p: Receptiveness refers to a willingness to access, consider, and evaluate opposing views in an impartial manner (Hussein & Tormala, 2021;Minson, Chen, & Tinsley, 2020;Yeomans et al., 2020). Prior research reveals that individuals higher in dispositional receptiveness are more likely to consume information from the opposite side of the political aisle, pay greater attention to such content once it is in front of them, and evaluate it more impartially once they have finished consuming it (Minson, Chen, & Tinsley, 2020). As such, prior research suggests that receptive individuals will penalize disagreement less than their less receptive counterparts.

Might receptiveness also influence the likelihood than an observer agrees with a target's biased decision? Receptive people are not necessarily more likely to be more persuaded (for review, see Minson & Chen, 2022). However, there is some evidence that individuals higher in receptiveness are less likely to show biases relevant to even-handed information exposure and processing (e.g., confirmation bias; Minson, Chen, & Tinsley, 2020). In this subset of cases, RRT would predict that the benefit of bias is less likely to hold for those specific biases because receptive observers are less likely to show them.

Altogether, receptiveness to opposing views presents an intriguing and nuanced component of RRT. Receptive individuals will likely penalize disagreement less but be similarly likely to disagree with biased targets-except for biases relevant to the construct itself, such as confirmation bias.

div.head: iv. Neglect of External Demands
div.p: A large literature documents the correspondence bias: the tendency to infer stable personality traits from the behavior of others while relatively neglecting external factors that contributed to the behavior. That is, they make overly correspondent inferences (Gilbert & Malone, 1995;Ross, 1977). But just as bias blind spot can vary across individuals, so can this correspondence bias:

people vary in the extent to which they neglect external demands when inferring traits from others' behaviors (Scopelliti et al., 2018). Individuals higher in correspondence bias are more likely attribute blame for accidental harms, neglect task difficulty when assessing performance, and believe a coerced confession (Scopelliti et al., 2018).
Unlike the other individual difference measures described above, individual differences in correspondence bias may shift whether inferences about the target are likely to occur at all.

That is, prior research provides evidence for the hypothesis that individuals lower in correspondence bias will be less likely to infer underlying personality characteristics from observed behavior. In this way, individual differences in correspondence bias are likely to shape the magnitude of the benefit of bias. For individuals higher in neglect of external demands, inferences may be amplified; for those lower in neglect of external demands, inferences may be dampened.

div.head: E. Summary
div.p: While the primary pathway of observer agreement gives the veneer of simplicity, RRT incorporates a variety of additional components and mechanisms to specify the conditions under which biased behavior is more vs. less likely to confer reputational advantages. Decision, target, and audience characteristics may conspire to amplify, eliminate, or even reverse the benefit of bias.

So far, RRT has focused primarily on how the set of beliefs or opinions held by observers about a decision maker (i.e., reputation). Building on this foundation and related theorizing (Tetlock, 1999(Tetlock, , 2000(Tetlock, , 2002, the following section considers when and why reputational incentives are more vs. less likely to reinforce decision biases.

div.head: III. Feedback Loops
div.p: Reputations serve a social function: they impact whether others cooperate with us, trust us, elect us, hire us, and marry us (Jordan, 2023). Indeed, Tetlock (1999) has argued that decision makers can often be fruitfully characterized as "intuitive politicians," navigating accountability demands from key stakeholders in their lives. A key tenet of this intuitive politician research programand much of the resulting empirical work on accountability and impression management-is that individuals suffer negative consequences when they fail to successfully manage their reputations.

The link between decision making, reputation, and material consequences is central to the idea of feedback loops and the persistence of bias (Tetlock, 1992(Tetlock, , 2000(Tetlock, , 2002. A large prior research literature on accountability generates and tests predictions for when and why the presence of an evaluative audience increases, decreases, or has no effect on tendency to display a decision bias in the moment (Lerner & Tetlock, 1999). As a complement, RRT investigates the conditions under which biased behavior by a target improves, degrades, or has no effect on how an observer evaluates them.

But key questions also remain regarding the conditions under which evaluations will As with the core construction of RRT, this section aims to balance parsimony and predictive power. In doing so, it has similar key limitations to those described above: not only is this list not comprehensive, but also it does not specify interactions between components.
Identifying the conditions under which these characteristics (and others) interact with each other should be a fruitful line of empirical research going forward.

div.head: A. Observer's relationship with the decision maker
div.p: Different social relationships demand different traits. Consider two types of relationships: one with the president of your organization and one with your spouse. While in theory we'd prefer both individuals to encompass all positive traits, we are often forced to make trade-offs across attributes, prioritizing one over the other. Would you prefer a CEO who is competent in handling complex financial statements or who is beloved by your family? Would your choice change for your spouse? The traits we may prioritize in a leader (e.g., financial competence) are different than the traits we may prioritize in a spouse (e.g., interpersonal warmth).

This prioritization-and therefore the match between the reputational inference and the relationship between the observer and the target-can shape whether reputational outcomes "matter" (i.e., the extent to which they translate to material outcomes relevant to a decision maker's goals). For example, if a target is judged as disorganized-and is applying for a job as a project manager-this judgment is very likely to be costly. Instead, if a target is judged as disorganized-and is applying for a job as an artist-this judgment is less likely to be costly. How does this apply to RRT? Consider the results by Belmi and colleagues (2020) described earlier linking overconfidence and status attainment. In the context of a mock job interview, the authors found that overconfidence triggered perceptions of confidence, which in predicted likelihood of attaining social rank (in this case, being perceived as more hirable). This is a straightforward example of a feedback loop of the type initially proposed by Tetlock and colleagues: overconfidence triggers reputational benefits, which trigger material outcomes-in turn likely propagating the likelihood of demonstrating overconfidence in the future when observed by an evaluative audience. However, within the context of RRT, the SCH Model identifies a potential break in this link. Consider if the context was not hiring, but instead was a close interpersonal relationship focused on warmth and benevolence. To the extent that the reputational benefits of overconfidence are limited to competence (vs. warmth), they are less likely to provide benefits-and thus socially reinforce the bias-when the relationship preferentially relies on a different set of attributes (here, warmth).

A similar analysis could be applied to other decision biases. Consider again the three college students described earlier in this article: Ethan (who procrastinates studying by watching trashy television), Justin (another procrastinator who often scrambles to order delivery before the local pizza shop closes), and Liam (the paragon of self-control who studies weeks in advance and adheres to a nightly skincare routine). Assuming that Ethan judges Justin as relatively warmer and Liam as relatively more competent, how these evaluations translate to material outcomes will depend on whether Ethan is searching for a friend for a weekend activity (rewarding Justin) or a study partner (rewarding Liam).

These dynamics yield testable predictions for which types of decision biases will be rewarded in different contexts. For example, overconfidence may be more likely to be socially reinforced in work contexts requiring perceptions of competence. In contrast, procrastination may be more likely to be socially reinforced in collegial contexts requiring perceptions of warmth. Indeed, it is not uncommon to hear students on college campuses bragging about their late-night study habits. Unfortunately, prior research tends to examine a single decision bias (e.g., overconfidence) in a single context (e.g., status attainment), often examining only a single type of social perception (e.g., competence). Future research is needed to test these hypotheses more directly within a single paradigm to provide a stronger test of this theorizing.

div.head: B. Observer's structural power
div.p: While power can be defined in many ways, influential recent work defines it as one's control over valued resources (Magee & Galinsky, 2008). In contrast to status (the extent to which an individual or group is respected by others), power describes a relative state of dependence, typically between two individuals, and is grounded in differential access to valued resources.

Almost definitionally, high-power individuals can shape outcomes for low-power individuals; the reverse is less often true. As an example, consider two members of an academic department: Talia (a tenured professor and department chair) and Uriel (an untenured assistant professor who is up for tenure the following year). Here, Talia is relatively higher power: she wields influence over a valued resource (here, tenure weakening the possibility for reputation-mediated feedback loops.

div.head: C. Observer's concern with their own reputation
div.p: Thus far, our discussion has assumed that when an observer positively evaluates a target's decision, the observer will be more likely to treat the target positively. But when observers decide how to treat targets, they may be concerned not just with their personal assessment of the target's decision-making, but also with how their treatment of the target will influence their own reputation. And importantly, the reputational consequences of an observer's treatment of a target will depend on how others assess the target's decision-making. As such, when predicting how a target's level of bias will influence the way that observers treat them, we must consider not just what the observer thinks of the target (i.e., her first-order beliefs about the target's qualities) but also what the observer thinks that others think of the target (i.e., her higher-order beliefs about the target's public reputation in the eyes of others). Within the context of cooperation, Jordan's (2023) innovative "pull versus push" framework for reputation provides a useful game-theoretic perspective on the interplay between these two factors-and how they might modulate when and how an observer's personal evaluation of a target influences her behavior toward the target.

The "pull versus push" framework suggests that observers may be pulled towards reputationally rewarding targets based on their own first-order evaluations of the target's positive qualities, or pushed towards reputationally rewarding targets because they expect others to view such rewarding positively. As an illustrative example, consider two work colleagues-Olivia and Tom-who are both firm believers in Bayesian reasoning and updating. As an example of a "pull" mechanism, Olivia may be pulled towards inviting Tom to join her new startup because she admires his adherence to Bayesian reasoning and sees it as a positive signal of his likely contributions to her company. In contrast, under push mechanisms (often called indirect reciprocity; Alexander, 1987;Boyd & Richerson, 1989), Olivia's behavior toward Tom is influenced by how she believes that others view Tom. But now also consider Olivia and Tom's boss: Ivan. Of note, Ivan is also a firm believer in Bayesian reasoning and therefore thinks very positively of Tom. Therefore, Olivia might be pushed toward inviting Tom to join her startup because she believes that inviting him will be regarded positively by Ivan, and she values Ivan's approval.

When pull and push mechanisms are aligned, it can amplify the link between Olivia's personal evaluation of Tom's decision-making and her behavior towards him. In the case of the three colleagues above, if Olivia and Ivan have the same evaluation of Tom, then such push pressures can reinforce the already-existing pull motives that Olivia has to hire Tom, increasing the probability that Olivia's positive evaluation of Tom leads her to invite him (instead of a competing candidate) to join her new venture.

But now consider what happens when push and pull pressures are misaligned. Imagine the same scenario as above, with one key difference: Ivan excoriates those who engage in Bayesian updating, instead believing that moral people should stick to their commitments and beliefs. As a result, Ivan thinks very negatively of Tom. Here, the "push" pressure from Ivanwhich would push Olivia away from hiring Tom-could interfere with Olivia's "pull" motive to hire Tom and reap the benefits of his rational decision-making. In this case, the "push" pressure increases the chance that the benefit of bias holds (that is, that Olivia avoids Tom despite his adherence to Bayesian updating).

Alternatively, "push" pressures could diminish the benefits of bias. If Olivia and Tom decry Bayesian reasoning-but Ivan admires it-then push pressures from Ivan can decrease the chance that Olivia rewards Tom for eschewing Bayesian updating (thus decreasing the benefits of bias). Thus, the broader principle is that when push and pull pressures are misaligned, it can eliminate-or even reverse-the usual link between an observer's personal evaluation of a decision-maker, and behavioral outcomes (here, Olivia's hiring behavior toward Tom).
When will the misalignment between push vs. pull provide the strongest divergence between an observer's personal evaluation of a decision maker and an observer's behavior

div.head: D. Summary
div.p: In general, reputations matter. But how much they matter and for whom they matter varies across contexts. This section identifies three such external contextual variables that can amplify, dampen, or have no effect on the linkage between reputation and material outcomes. In doing so, it provides novel testable hypotheses for when and why social pressures can reinforce biased behavior by offsetting the material costs of decision biases.

div.head: IV. Implications for judgment and decision making
div.p: RRT provides a theoretical model of how observers evaluate targets who do (vs. do not) strictly adhere to normative standards of judgment and choice. In doing so, it can provide novel insight into canonical puzzles in judgment and decision making while simultaneously emphasizing underappreciated avenues for inquiry.

div.head: A. Canonical puzzles i. What is rational?
div.p: In scholarly work, the proper definition of rationality has been debated-often quite vigorously-for centuries. As Frank (1988, p. 2) quipped, "There are almost as many definitions of rationality as there are people who have written on the subject." And as Tetlock and Mellers (2002, p. 97) observed, "the debate over human rationality is a high-stakes controversy that mixes primordial political and psychological prejudices in combustible combinations." RRT does not try to resolve this debate-but it does hope to contribute productively to it.

So far, to maximize comparability with influential research in the heuristics-and-biases tradition (Kahneman, Slovic, & Tversky, 1982), the present manuscript has adopted a definition of procedural rationality consistent with neoclassical economics and rational choice theory (e.g., Savage, 1954). Rationality has therefore been defined as adherence to axioms, where such adherence is classified as normatively correct (what has sometimes been termed "axiomatic rationality"). The perspective that deviations from narrow models of rationality constitute errors in need of correction is inherent in the names scholars give to tendencies and phenomena. The fundamental attribution error. Sunk cost bias. Conjunction fallacy.

In contrast to procedural rationality that centers choice axioms, one common alternative definition of rationality in psychology revolves around studying rationality in more naturalized contexts (e.g., ecological rationality). To directly quote Gigerenzer, ecological rationality "…differs from logical rationality in that it does not compare behavior with some principle of logic or probability that is taken to be universally true (2021, p. 66). Viale concurred, perhaps going even further: "…the canons of neoclassical rationality are unjustified both descriptively and normatively. Therefore, the reasoning errors, fallacies, and biases that behavioural economists are engaged to overcome most of the time are not irrationalities" (2021, p. 24).

While not fully in line with either approach, RRT aligns most closely with a goaloriented definition of instrumental rationality-where rationality is judged by whether actions serve a target's goals, as judged by targets themselves. In his groundbreaking work, Simon (1964, p. 1) defined rationality as "a style of behavior (a) that is appropriate to the achievement of given goals, (b) within the limits imposed by given conditions and constraints." In his popular press book titled Rationality, Pinker (2021, p. 35) defined rationality as "the ability to use knowledge to attain goals." Stanovich (2021, p. 203) operationalized instrumental rationality as "behaving in the world so that you get exactly what you most want." Finally, Anderson (1991, p. 409) argued that, in a rational analysis, "the first task is to specify what the system is trying to optimize."

RRT fits comfortably under the classic goal-oriented definitions of instrumental rationality. More concretely, a fundamental assumption is that reputational goals should be considered in the rationality equation, and thus impact classification of whether behavioral tendencies are irrational biases (for related discussion, see Lerner & Tetlock, 1999, p. 269). In doing so, RRT suggests that some prior behavioral decision research may have been too quick to classify certain judgments and choices as irrational mistakes. In light of a reputation-inclusive goal set, many tendencies that have been classified as wholly irrational or maladaptive can instead be classified as (sometimes) instrumentally rational. In this way, Tetlock's (2002, p. 453) two-decade-old challenge rings true: "…social functionalist theories should also identify normative boundary conditions that specify when it is reasonable to challenge extant classifications of judgmental tendencies as errors and biases."

RRT does not suggest that errors and biases are always rational just because observers fall victim to them and might therefore positively evaluate a target decision maker. Errors can be irrational even when they confer reputational benefits, if the material costs of the error are larger than the reputational benefits thereof. Catastrophes like the Salem Witch Trials were not "rational" simply because people agreed with each other. The crowd can clearly get things wrong.

Instead, the conclusion is more nuanced: researchers must carefully consider how individuals balance reputational and non-reputational incentives. In some cases, differences in reputational incentives may be relatively small. For example, consider the CEO of a promising technology start-up assessing different offer sheets from investors. One offer sheet values the company at $10 million; the other offer sheet values the company at $100 million. How should the CEO weight the financial packages compared to how the public will evaluate her choice of investor? In cases like these, differences in non-reputational incentives likely dominate differences in reputational incentives.

In other cases, reputational incentives may outweigh non-reputational ones. Consider a governor in the weeks before an election debating between two policy responses to address homelessness. One policy response is relatively tougher; the other policy response is relatively more lenient. After carefully evaluating the responses, she believes that the tougher policy response will be minimally more effective. And yet, the public-who will imminently be voting-strongly distrusts the tougher response. In cases like these, where reputational incentives loom large, the well-documented costs of supposed errors could be dwarfed by the reputational benefits of the path of least resistance. From the perspective of RRT, it is not unreasonable to classify the governor selecting more lenient response as rational, given that it boosts her reelection goals at minimal costs to her policy goals. 5

Finally, it is worth noting that RRT allows for both the intentional or unintentional fulfillment of such goals. This claim is in line with classic work by Simon (1978, p. 3-4) who, in his canonical work on bounded rationality, suggested that "It is not necessary or implied that the adaption of institutions or behavior patterns of goals be conscious or intended." This perspective is echoed in recent influential empirical work in economics: Nielsen and Rehbeck (2022) remained "agnostic on the source of mistakes, but define a mistake as a violation of an axiom that would not be maintained after the decision-maker understands the full implications of the axioms and their choices" (p. 2237, Footnote 2; emphasis added).

In sum, RRT takes a relatively intermediate position on this age-old and sometimesincendiary question of human rationality. On the one hand, it tacitly accepts choice axioms as a useful starting benchmark for rationality. On the other hand, it suggests that deviations from such benchmarks should not invariably be considered irrational. Finally, it takes a firm stance that intentionality is not a necessary ingredient for a behavior to be considered rational, as long as it achieves a decision maker's goals. Looking ahead, much more research is needed to understand the conditions under which deviations from choice axioms can and should be considered reputationally rational.
ii. Where do decision biases come from and why do they persist?

Decision biases can incur substantial costs for individuals, organizations, and even societies, wasting money and putting lives at risk. Despite these costs, one of the most remarkable findings from the judgment and decision-making literature is the persistence of cognitive biases among experts. Substantial bias exists among physicians (McNeil, Pauker, Sox, & Tversky, 1982), philosophers (Schwitzgebel & Cushman, 2015), and real estate professionals (Northcraft & Neale, 1987). Given their costs, where do decision biases come from and why do they persist?

Building off prior social functionalist approaches (Tetlock, 1991), and as a complement to prior research on cognitive limitations on human judgment and decision making, RRT sheds fresh light these questions.
First, RRT can shed new light on the origin of decision biases. Consider the program of research on error management theory (Haselton & Buss, 2000;Haselton & Nettle, 2006).

Drawing on an evolutionary lens of analysis, this research program argues that if the costs of false positive and false negative errors are asymmetric, then systematically biased behaviors can reduce costly errors over time, even compared to non-biased behaviors. For example, error management theory predicts and explains both men's overestimation of women's sexual intent and women's underestimation of men's commitment because both alleged errors produce functional evolutionary strategies (Haselton & Buss, 2000). From this perspective, these over and underestimations are not errors at all, but rather useful adaptations aimed at minimizing costly errors (while tolerating less costly ones). As a concrete example connecting this type of thinking to RRT, consider escalation of commitment. In many situations, it may be more important for a social partner to be too committed rather than too uncommitted. As such, excess commitment-possibly in the form of sunk-cost bias-may be reputationally adaptive, even if it carries concomitant material costs and even if homophily is not occurring. and are thus evolutionarily functional (e.g., Arkes, 1991;Einhorn & Hogarth, 1981, p. 58;Gilovich & Griffin, 2002). For example, Kahan and colleagues introduced the concept of expressive rationality, in which decisions can be interpreted partially as advertisements for an individual's underlying traits or beliefs (Kahan, 2013;Kahan et al., 2017)-and thus inaccurate beliefs can still serve a functional goal in that they reinforce group identity. While Kahan and colleagues primarily investigate political beliefs, RRT generalizes this line of logic to behavioral decision making more generally.

div.head: iii. How can de-biasing efforts be improved?
div.p: Initial perspectives on cognitive de-biasing training were pessimistic (e.g., Fischhoff, 1982;Milkman, Chugh, & Bazerman, 2009); however, recent empirical efforts focused on individuallevel training have shown promise (for an alternative perspective, see Gobet & Sala, 2023). For example, Morewedge and colleagues developed realistic video games to teach individuals about their cognitive biases, and recent work revealed that de-biasing training can improve decision making in new settings (Morewedge et al., 2015;Sellier, Scopelliti, & Morewedge, 2019; see also Chang, Chen, Mellers, & Tetlock, 2016;Fong, Krantz, & Nisbett, 1986;Fong & Nisbett, 1991;Ho, Budescu, Dhami, & Mandel, 2015;Larrick, Morgan, & Nisbett, 1990). Related work on the policy prospects of boosting-training aimed at fostering people's competence to make their own choices-builds directly on this idea that individual decision making can be improved and that cognitive limitations can be overcome (Boissin, Caparos, Raoelison, & De Neys, 2021;Hertwig & Grune-Yanoff, 2017;Kurvers et al., 2016;Mandel, Karvetski, & Dhami, 2018). In one notable series of field experiments, Heller and colleagues (2017) assessed the consequences of an intervention teaching low-income youths in Chicago to slow down and reflect on their construal of situations. Strikingly, taking part in this training intervention reduced arrests by approximately 30% and increased graduation rates by over 10%. 6

RRT generates at least two novel insights for when such de-biasing efforts will be more vs. less effective. First, de-biasing training is more likely to be effective when trained decision makers are insulated from countervailing reputational pressures. In contrast, de-biasing training is less likely to be effective when trained decision makers are confronted with strong countervailing reputational pressures. Indeed, a provocative possibility is that-after de-biasing training-a decision maker may continue to demonstrate the bias, despite actively endorsing it as a costly mistake. Second, de-biasing training is more likely to be effective when groups (rather 6 As a complement to individual-level training, interventions focused on situational factors have been met with enthusiastic interest (Thaler & Sunstein, 2008.
