Building on an understanding of cognitive biases, this work has proposed and tested the effectiveness of "nudges" -interventions which attempt to subtly alter people's behavior without shifting underlying incentives or restricting choice itself. Nudge units have proliferated in governments around the world, changing behavior with minimal marginal cost (Benartzi et al., 2017; but see Chater & Loewenstein, 2022;Hallsworth, 2023;Johnson et al., 2012;Reiff et al., 2022). than individuals) are trained. Following a similar logic to above, shifting norms about decision biases can in turn undermine countervailing reputational pressures. For example, if all eight people on an executive team learn about overconfidence, then an overconfident CEO will be less likely to be perceived as competence-and therefore should be more likely to qualify their claims. If contrast, if only the CEO received training, she may still feel pressured to project undue confidence, even if she internally acknowledges the perils of doing so.

div.head: B. Novel questions
div.p: RRT not only addresses enduring questions within judgment and decision making, but also points to underappreciated new ones.

div.head: i. Are inferences accurate?
div.p: Social perceptions are useful to observers only to the extent that they successfully predict how a target will behave in the future. Many reputational outcomes, such as warmth or intelligence, are quite complex to benchmark against a "right" answer. It is difficult (although perhaps not impossible) for researchers to reliably assess how competent or moral someone is. To reduce this inherent complexity, researchers have used financially incentivized economic games to measure trust, which allows for concrete testing of whether inferences of trustworthiness match actual trustworthiness within the same economic game that the prediction was made in.

So, how accurate are the inferences of trustworthiness that observers draw about targets based on observed judgments and choices? While this question remains largely unanswered in the context of normative behavior, initial evidence from two papers briefly reviewed above suggests at least some modicum of accuracy (for related work on personality, see Costello & Srivastava, 2021). First, research by Jordan and colleagues (2016) found that (1) individuals who cooperated without calculating the costs and benefits of doing so were trusted more by observers and (2) these very same individuals displayed greater levels of trustworthiness in an ensuing economic game. The same pattern emerges in the context of escalation of commitment : individuals who preferred escalation of commitment (vs. those who did not) were trusted more by third-party observers and returned more money in an ensuing trust game.
While these two papers provide tentative evidence of where inferences are accurate, empirical research remains scant.

div.head: ii. How do benefits of bias spread across people and time?
div.p: To date, evidence supporting the benefit of bias hypothesis almost exclusively examines perceptions of a single individual at the time a judgment or choice is made-mostly within the United States. This methodological approach necessarily excludes how reputations spread across people and across time.

On an interpersonal level of analysis, one key question is how reputational benefits spread across people in the form of gossip (Feinberg, Willer, Stellar, & Keltner, 2012). In a recent innovative paper, Costello and Srivastava (2021; see also Craik, 2008) Reputations can also be studied across time in the form of an individual's legacy in the minds of contemporaries. Typically studied in the context of intergenerational motivations like pro-environmental behavior (e.g., Zaval, Markowitz, & Weber, 2015;Wade-Benzoni, Tost, Hernandez, & Larrick, 2012; for review, see Wade-Benzoni, 2019), an open question is to what extent reputational benefits of cognitive biases serve as permanent stains vs. temporary smudges.

Could it be the case that observers learn over time that the original decision was the wrong oneand therefore the homophily pattern reverses? Alternatively, does the delay of time and the probabilistic nature of making the "wrong" choice obscure potential for learning, allowing for homophily to persist in its original direction?

Taking a cultural level of analysis also yields intriguing and testable future directions for how benefits of bias spread across people and time, especially regarding social signaling. For example, in cultures with high relational mobility, might escalation of commitment have an especially large boost to reputation because it signals that someone is remaining committed even though it is easy to shift to a new partner? Future research is needed on these and related questions taking complementary interpersonal and culture-level approaches.
iii.

div.head: How can individuals reduce reputational costs of rationality?
div.p: On the opposite end of benefits of bias are costs for rationality. RRT presents a problem: good decisions can make individuals look bad. But, outside of psychology experiments, decisions are not evaluated in isolation. Instead, individuals (and leaders) can explain, justify, and rationalize their choices to others. What should they say to garner trust and signal competence while making value-maximizing decisions? Answers to this question could come in three overlapping forms.

One empirical strategy is to start with a decision bias and then work from there to identify communication strategies that would work for that specific bias. This type of strategy is narrow in its specificity, working as a "lock and key" for a certain context. This lock-and-key approach was the one used by Kristal and Dorison (2023). In the context of escalation of commitment, the authors drew on past theorizing that one reason de-escalation undermines trust is because it engenders the appearance of inconsistency (see also Kreps, Laurin, & Merritt, 2017). Thus, they identified the strategy of precommitment (i.e., specifying how a decision will be made before the time of the choice) to cast de-escalation as consistent with a prior strategy, even among audiences who still disagree with the choice to de-escalate. In this way, leaders can harness specific communication tools to address specific decisions they must make-while bypassing the need to persuade everyone.

A second empirical strategy is more mid-range in specificity. That is, it can work for a class of biases, but not all biases. One potential such strategy is counterfactual reasoning (Byrne, 2016;Icard, Cushman, & Knobe, 2018). Humans live in a between-subjects world. For any given decision, we usually encounter only the high (but not low) sunk cost condition or the loss (but not gain) frame. It is only when the within-subjects nature of the decision bias is clarified that the error becomes apparent (c.f., Frisch, 1993). Using counterfactual reasoning as a communication tool-in which a target makes explicit how their choice could be framed differently-could prove effective for decision biases in which the equivalence of options become apparent when seen side-by-side (e.g., loss-gain framing effects). Of note, counterfactual reasoning is likely to operate by reducing disagreement (i.e., through persuasion) rather than by reducing the costs of disagreement.

Finally, a third type of strategy is domain general. That is, it is a communication strategy that is agnostic to the specific decision and signals positive traits. One such potential strategy of interest-untested to date in this context-is conversational receptiveness: the use of language to communicate one's willingness to thoughtfully engage with opposing views (Yeomans et al., 2020;Minson, Chen, & Tinsley, 2020;Minson & Chen, 2022;Hussein & Tormala, 2021). Prior research in the context of disagreement over partisan politics in the United States reveals that conversational receptiveness boosts perceptions of an individual as a better teammate and advisor. The same might be true for leaders defending rational decisions to audiences who fall victim to cognitive biases. Thus, receptiveness could signal positive underlying traitsregardless of specific domain-even without persuading observers of the correctness of the leader's choice. That is, it could reduce the costs of disagreement, while not reducing disagreement itself.

Together, these three sets of strategies demonstrate the varied communication strategies individuals can use to shift their reputational incentives. Future research is needed to empirically validate them and assess boundary conditions on their effectiveness.

div.head: V. Conclusion
div.p: RRT draws on prior cognitive and social approaches to judgment and decision making, but it also goes beyond them. Traditionally, behavioral decision researchers have drawn on cognitive psychology to identify deviations from normative standards of judgment and choice; these deviations are often considered irrational mistakes. While a relative minority, researchers taking a social approach to judgment and decision making have identified how social pressures amplify vs. attenuate these deviations from normative standards. Merging insights from both approaches, the present manuscript proposes RRT as a theoretical model of how observers evaluate targets who do (vs. do not) strictly adhere to normative standards of judgment and choice. The theory generates testable predictions regarding when and why observers positively evaluate error-prone decision makers, termed the benefit of bias hypothesis. Given that individuals hold deep impression management goals, reputational rationality theory challenges the unqualified classification of response tendencies that deviate from normative standards as invariably

figure.head: Figure 1
figure.figDesc: specifies the model. RRT contains one general pathway underpinning the benefit of bias hypothesis: observer agreement. The core of the theory is that observers themselves exhibit cognitive biases and reputationally reward targets who have similar preferences. Beyond agreement, RRT also discusses three key sets of components and mechanisms likely to moderate this general pathway. These components include aspects of the decision, target, and audience. Drawing on past work, each component provides testable hypotheses for the conditions under which the benefit of bias is more vs. less likely to hold, often as a function of the central agreement pathway. While Section II focuses on observer evaluations (i.e., reputation) as the focal outcome variable, Section III (Feedback Loops) considers additional contextual factors dictating when and why reputational outcomes in the eyes of observers are more or less likely to translate to material outcomes for a focal decision maker.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: A simplified conceptual framework detailing Reputational Rationality Theory (solid lines) and how reputational incentives can reinforce biased behavior (dotted lines).

translate to behavior relevant to the target-thus closing and reinforcing the feedback loop. Put another way, a critical open question for both past research on accountability and the present work on RRT is understanding when reputation in the eyes of an observer matters. While reputation can trigger concomitant material and strategic rewards for a decision maker, it is critical to understand the contextual features shaping when and why an observer's evaluation trigger material benefits for a decision maker.This section discusses three such external contextual features. These include the observer's relationship with the target, the observer's structural power relative to the target, and the observer's concern with their own reputation. These features generate novel testable hypotheses for when the costs of judgmental errors are offset by social or political benefits, as mediated through reputation. Additionally, and as described later, they help deepen understanding regarding and origin, persistence, and potential alleviation of cognitive biases dynamically over time.

The Size-Closeness-Hierarchy (SCH) Model recently proposed byMoore and colleagues (2023) provides a systematic framework for understanding exactly this type of matching. TheSCH Model provides testable hypotheses for how preferences for benevolence and integrity shift across emerging relationships. More concretely, the authors propose that relationships characterized by emotional intimacy and equality in structural power lead individuals to prioritize counterparts high in benevolence. Examples include a close friend or work peer. In contrast, relationships characterized by emotional distance and relative power imbalances lead individuals to prioritize individuals high in integrity. Examples include a political leader or corporate CEO. While both benevolence and integrity are valuable, their relative value shifts as a function of the nature of the relationship.

Second, RRT can shed new light on the persistence of decision biases. Consider a reality in which the origins of decision biases-such as loss-gain framing effects on risk preferencesare exclusively cognitive. Even when decision biases have cognitive origins, RRT converges with other social functionalist approaches to suggest that they can be reputationally reinforced over time. For example, even if such framing effects originate from non-social causes, social pressures may still reinforce and maintain them over time through homophily. This reputational perspective converges with related theorizing that apparent judgmental errors can have benefits,

conceptualized reputation as information about an individual stored in networks of perceivers. Critically, reputational benefits of cognitive biases could spread through networks, without evaluators ever having met the target. Are reputational benefits amplified or attenuated as reputations spread through a network? How do different dimensions of reputation (e.g., warmth vs. competence) differ? And what linguistic words or phrases are used to convey information, such as agreement with a target's choice?

Finally, studies typically considered one type of target or one type of audience, often without considering how such results may generalize to other types of targets or other types of audiences.As such, several critical questions remain. Why do such effects occur? Under what conditions are they most likely to obtain? What aspects of reputation are more vs. less likely to be affected? And finally, when are reputational outcomes likely to translate to material ones?

).Dorison and Heller (2022) provided perhaps the most direct empirical evidence for relatively broad inferences in the context of the benefit of bias hypothesis. As described previously, the authors used established scenarios developed by Kahneman and Tversky for lossgain framing effects on risk preferences. While third-party observers rewarded decision makers who made risk-seeking (vs. risk-averse) choices when choice outcomes were framed as losses, this result reversed when outcomes were framed as gains. Critically, this reversal was mediated by alignment between observers' and targets' risk preferences (i.e., observers themselves fell victim to framing effects) and generalized across a variety of social perceptions (e.g., warmth, competence, and confidence, among others). Simply put, people appeared to think to themselves "what would I do in this situation" and then made positive social judgments of targets who made the same choice. This type of broad attribution process is perhaps most likely to occur in lowinformation domains where an observer does not have additional differentiating information about the target; however, future research is needed to test this specific possibility.

Justin is similar: he regularly finds himself cramming before a big exam while scrambling to order food for delivery before the local pizza shop closes for the night. In contrast, Liam is the paragon of self-control: he wakes up before sunrise to go for a 6-mile run and makes study guides in advance. He even adheres to a nightly skincare routine. Now imagine two choices facing Ethan. First, Ethan needs to decide who should lead a group project worth 50% of his final grade in an important course. Given that this role relies on competence, Ethan is likely to seek out Liam, despite his similarity with Justin. But now imagine instead that Ethan needs to find a friend for lunch. Given that lunch relies on having a warm and friendly companion, Ethan seeks out Justin.This example illustrates how insight into one's own bias (here, procrastination) can shape perceptions of others who do vs. do not share that bias. When an individual correctly acknowledges their behavior as biased, they may perceive an unbiased target as relatively competent-but relatively less warm. On the flip side, they may evaluate their similarly-biased
figure.note: Ericson, Laibson, & White, 2020; Ericson & Laibson, 2019; Frederick, Loewenstein, & O'Donoghue, 2002) posits a central role for self-awareness regarding one's own level of procrastination (O'Donoghue & Rabin, 1999, 2001). When individuals have insight into their own undesirable tendencies (such as present- focused preferences), they may be more willing to reward others who do not show them. Consider three college students: Ethan, Liam, and Justin. Ethan tends to procrastinate. And he knows it. He binges trashy television and complaining about his mounting pile of homework.counterpart as relatively warmer-but relatively less competent. RRT returns to this distinction between different aspects of reputation and different social relationships in Section III.

body.note: In many cases, not taking advice from a focal advisor could improve accuracy if other advice is more compelling-a possibility that could conflict with impression management goals.

Relatedly, prior research often defines social power as asymmetric control over valued resources in social relations. Power (more than status) is a property of a target, whereas status (more than power) is a property of an observer.

This type of calculus is analogous to the welfare analysis proposed byAllcott and Kessler (2019) in the context of nudge-style interventions (see alsoZlatev & Rogers, 2020). While these interventions are designed to change behavior with minimal marginal cost, relatively rarely had prior research considered the emotional costs of being nudged. For example, while a home energy report informing a consumer they use more energy than their neighbor may confer behavioral benefits (e.g., reduced energy usage), it might simultaneously confer emotional costs (e.g., feelings of guilt). In the same way, behaviors that confer non-reputational benefits (e.g., increased accuracy) might simultaneously confer reputational costs (e.g., decreased trust). Future research is needed to model how decision makers balance reputational and non-reputational incentives over the short and long term, in which material and reputational outcomes conflict.

div.p: irrational. That is, apparent errors and biases can, under certain theoretical conditions, be reputationally rational.
